(a) The purpose of this section is to ensure that the citizens of the county will be afforded the best available emergency medical transportation in all circumstances. (b) All ambulances and emergency medical vehicles, which operate in the county, shall be certified for advanced life support by the state department of human resources. (c) Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or 60 days imprisonment, or both. Each day any violation continues shall be a separate offense. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § II) Sec. 22-21. - Affected services. (a) Application. This section and sections 22-22 through 22-24 shall apply to any ambulance service, except those listed below, which is proposed by any person to be located within the county or whose services are offered to county residents. (b) Exempt services. Exempt emergency medical services are: (1) An ambulance service operated by an agency of the United States government; (2) A vehicle operated by an individual who is not licensed to furnish emergency medical services and who is rendering assistance temporarily, such as in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency; or (3) An ambulance service which is based in another county, and which is returning county residents to the county from any other county. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § III) Sec. 22-22. - General operations regulations. (a) General compliance. All ambulance services, its vehicles and personnel shall at all times, be operated in compliance with all laws, rules, regulations, orders and decrees of the state and the county. (b) Base station. All ambulance services offering services to residents of the county must have a permanent base of operations located within the county. (c) Hours of operation. Every ambulance service offering services to residents of the county must provide said services 24 hours a day, seven days a week. (d) Staffing. All ambulance services offering services to residents of the county shall have at least two qualified and certified personnel on duty and available to answer calls for assistance, at all times. At least one of these individuals must be certified as a paramedic or a cardiac technician, or the equivalent as provided by the state law. (e) Vehicles. All vehicles operated by any ambulance service offering services to residents of the county shall be equipped to provide advanced life support at all times. (f) Public Access. All ambulance services offering services to residents of the county must not advertise or encourage the use of any other telephone number other than 9-1-1 for emergency calls. Said services must establish a local or toll-free telephone number for residents to arrange for non-emergency transportation and/or business calls. (g) Dispatch by E911. Any ambulance service offering service to residents of the county by receiving calls through E911 will share in the cost of operating the E911 emergency system. The county has determined that ten percent of the cost of operating the E911 emergency system is attributed to ambulance service in the county. Therefore, any ambulance service offering the aforesaid services shall share equally with all other ambulance services, including the county-operated ambulance service, ten percent of the cost of operating the E911 emergency system. Such amounts shall be determined by the county and billed to each such ambulance service on a monthly basis. Said ambulance service shall remit payment to the county within ten days of receipt of such statement. Failure to remit such monies to the county within the time specified shall be considered a violation of this article. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § IV) Sec. 22-23. - Indemnification. Any ambulance service that operates from a base of operations located within the county shall maintain the insurance listed below. (1) General and professional (e.g., malpractice) liability insurance on the private ambulance service of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence/$3,000,000.00 aggregate, and the manager/owner of the private ambulance service shall be named as an additional insured's on the policy. (2) Any person, firm or corporation owning or operating a private business providing ambulance service within the county shall indemnify and hold harmless the county and any resident of the county for any loss or damage resulting from the operations of the ambulance service. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § V) Sec. 22-24. - Supervision and administration. The board shall specify from time to time the division or agency of the county which shall have supervisory and enforcement authority with respect to the provisions of this article, whenever there are any requirements for the county to take any action or receive any action, the designated division or agency shall act on the behalf of the county. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § VI) Sec. 22-25. - Application for occupation tax certificate; review of application. No action on any application by an ambulance service for an occupation tax certificate shall be taken until the county board of commissioners has reviewed such application and forwarded their recommendation to the county clerk. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § VII) Sec. 22-26. - Occupation tax certificate fee. The annual fee for each ambulance service in the county shall be $1,000.00. Said fee shall be levied on an annual basis, based on the calendar year. Each ambulance service shall pay his annual occupation tax certificate fee, no later than January 30 of every calendar year. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § VIII) Sec. 22-27. - Renewal of occupation tax certificate. Renewal applications shall be submitted by January 1 of the year for which such occupation tax certificate is required. The applicant must continue to meet the requirements set out in this article. (Ord. of 1-4-2010, § IX) Secs. 22-28—22-57. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SALVAGE BUSINESSES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 22-58—22-87. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - JUNK DEALERS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.
Sec. 22-88. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Junk means any used article of commerce which is composed principally if iron, steel, brass, copper, zinc, or their alloys, or any other base metals and which is commonly bought for the purpose of resale or refabrication, or both. Junk dealer means any person, firm, or corporation or officer, agent, or employee of any person, firm, or corporation who engages in the purchase of junk for the purpose of resale or refabrication, or both. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.22.1) Sec. 22-89. - Registration with judge of probate court. No person, firm, or corporation or employee of any person, firm, or corporation shall engage in the business of purchasing junk in any county of this state without first registering his name with the judge of the probate court of the county in which he intends to engage in such business, the name to be entered upon a book in the judge's office, to be known as the junk dealers' book, and paying to the judge the registration fee as provided in section 22-90. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.22.2) Sec. 22-90. - Registration fee. The registration fee provided for in section 22-89 shall be $1.00, which shall be paid to the judge of the probate court at the time of registration by each person, firm, or corporation and by the individual agent and employee of any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of purchasing junk in such county. After the initial payment, a registration fee of $1.00 shall be paid annually by each junk dealer. All fees paid to the judge of the probate court under this chapter shall be and remain the property of the judge of the probate court, and the judge of the probate court shall issue to the person making such payment a proper receipt therefor. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 42.22.3) Sec. 22-91. - Written consent to enter another's property. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation or officer thereof or agent or employee of such person, firm, or corporation who is engaged in business as a junk dealer to enter upon the lands of another person, without the written consent of the owner or tenant in possession of such land, for the purpose of buying junk, or soliciting for the purpose of buying junk, or, after entering upon such land, to purchase or offer to purchase junk in any manner whatsoever. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.22.4) Sec. 22-92. - Penalty. Any person, firm, or corporation or office, agent, or employee thereof who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less that $50.00 nor more than $100.00, or imprisonment not to exceed six months, or both. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.22.5) Secs. 22-93—22-112. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - SCRAP METAL PROCESSORS[4] Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Scrap metal processors, O.C.G.A. § 43-43-1 et seq.
Subdivision I. - In General
Sec. 22-113. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Licensed seller means any person, firm, or corporation licensed by a state board of registration in this state for salvage dealers, dismantlers, or rebuilders which may be created. Scrap metal processor means any person, firm, or corporation which is engaged in the business of buying scrap vehicles, automotive parts, or other metallic waste by weight to process such material into scrap metal for remelting purposes; which utilizes machinery and equipment for processing ferrous and nonferrous metallic scrap into prepared grades; and whose principal product is metallic scrap. Scrap vehicle means any vehicle which has been crushed or flattened by mechanical means of which has been otherwise damaged to the extent that it cannot economically be repaired or made roadworthy. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.43.1) Sec. 22-114. - Maintenance of records required; contents; term. (a) Every scrap metal processor shall maintain records which shall contain in legible English the following information: (1) For all purchases of vehicles or scrap vehicle from licensed seller: a. The date of purchase; b. The name of the seller; c. A general description of the purchase; d. The number of scrap vehicles purchased; e. The vehicle identification number of vehicles which are not scrap vehicles, if available; or, if not available, a notation of the make and year of such vehicles; and f. The amount paid for the purchase. (2) For all purchases of vehicles or scrap vehicles for nonresident sellers or sellers who are not licensed: a. The date of purchase; b. The name and address of the seller; c. The name and motor vehicle operator's license number of the driver delivering the material; d. A general description of the purchase; e. The number of scrap vehicles purchased; f. The vehicle identification number, if available, of vehicles purchased which are not scrap vehicles; or, if not available, a notation of the make and year of such vehicles; and g. The amount paid for the purchase. (b) The records required by this section shall be maintained for a period of not less than two years. (c) The records required by this section shall be open to the inspection of any duly authorized law enforcement officer during the ordinary hours of business. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.43.2) Sec. 22-115. - Vehicle certificate of title or license plate to be transmitted to department of revenue upon receipt. Should a scrap metal processor be presented the certificate of title or vehicle license plate for any vehicle or scrap vehicle purchased, that scrap metal processor shall mail or deliver the same to the department of revenue as required by law. In lieu of a certificate of title, an affidavit in accordance with the provisions of state law shall be obtained by a scrap metal processor. All other requirements of state law shall be complied with, including maintenance of a copy of such affidavit, and any other rules promulgated pursuant thereto. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.43.3) Sec. 22-116. - Local laws as cumulative to this division. Nothing in this division shall supersede existing local laws or relieve a scrap metal processor from the necessity of complying with them. The requirements of local laws shall be construed as cumulative of this division. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.43.4) Sec. 22-117. - Penalties. Any scrap metal processor or his agent who: (1) Fails to make an entry of any material matter in his records; (2) Makes any false entry therein; (3) Falsifies, obliterates, destroys or removes from his place of business such records; (4) Refuses to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect such records or any vehicles or scrap vehicles in his possession during the ordinary hours of business; (5) Fails to maintain the records required by section 22-86 for at least two years shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1), § 43.43.5) Secs. 22-118—22-147. - Reserved. Subdivision II. - Scrap Metal Recycling Facilities
Sec. 22-148. - Purpose; requirements. (a) Purpose. The purpose of this subdivision is to regulate the conduct and activities of scrap metal recycling facilities as defined herein, in order to reduce and curtail criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses; to aid the county sheriff's office in detection and prevention, and to ensure fair dealing between the recycling center and their customers. (b) Requirements. Any person applying for occupation tax certificate to operate salvage after date of enactment of the ordinance from which this subdivision is derived shall: (1) Own no fewer than 15 acres in one location that can be used for salvage business. (2) Establish a minimum 50-foot setback from all property lines. (3) Install an eight-foot chainlink fencing with mesh webbing or be screened by natural objects or other appropriate means removing from sight so as not to be visible from the main roadway or surrounding property. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-149. - Definitions. In this chapter, the following terms shall have the indicated meanings, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accepted identification means a valid driver's license or identification card issued by one of the 50 United States, or a branch of the U.S. military, i.e., Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, or Coast Guard. The identification must as a minimum bear a true photograph of the person presenting it, date of birth, a description of the person, and an address for the person. No foreign identification and no passports of any type are acceptable. This identification will be physically presented for each transaction. If the identification is not state issued the employee will request the customer supply a local address to be used rather than the address listed on the out of state identification. Deceptive business practices means any of the following: (1) Any use or possession of a false weight or measurement, or any other device for falsely determining or recording any quality or quantity in connection with any scale or service; (2) Any sale or offer to sell or delivery of less than the represented quality or quantity; (3) Any attempt to take more than the represented quantity of any commodity, when as buyer or broker, he furnishes the weight or measure; (4) Any service which is of an unreasonably lesser quality than the service offered or represented; (5) Any other practice designated as unlawful by O.C.G.A. § 10-1-390 et seq.; (6) Any other fraudulent business transaction that is made punishable by the laws of the state. The term "scrap metal/secondary metals recycler" means any person operating from a fixed location or otherwise in the business of paying compensation or in any way buying, selling, exchanging, trading, or dealing in scrap iron, brass, wire, cable, copper, lead, solder, motor vehicles or secondhand metals of any sort, including catalytic converters, and automobile parts. Fencing means an eight-foot chainlink fence with mesh webbing that will obscure the operation from site around recycling facility or junk yard. All established salvage businesses in operation on the date the ordinance from which this article is derived is enacted shall be allowed 180 days from said date to install required fencing. Ferrous metals means any metals containing significant quantities of iron or steel. Good moral character means a person is of good moral character according to this article if that person has not been convicted of any felony or any crime involving theft, fraud or a crime against property in the past ten years. Law enforcement officer means any duly constituted peace officer of the state or of any county, municipality, or political subdivision thereof. Minor, for the purposes of this article, means any person who has not attained the age of 17 years. Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle originally manufactured to include an engine of any kind which propels the vehicle across the ground on wheels, tracks, or any combination thereof. Non-ferrous metals mean any metals not containing significant quantities of iron or steel, including without limitation, copper, brass, aluminum, bronze, lead, zinc, nickel and alloys thereof. Occupation tax certificate means certification issues to the salvage business that it has filed an appropriate application, paid the designated tax and is in compliance with the county salvage ordinance and state law pursuant to a review by the sheriff of the county and the board of commissioners for the county. Penalties may be monetary, jail time, or both, as well as civil actions against the applicant's permit and/or occupation tax certificate for failure to comply. Person or customer means an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association, and any other legal entity bringing materials either ferrous or non-ferrous or motor vehicle to the scrap metal recycling facility in exchange for monetary reward. Purchase transaction means a transaction in which a secondary metals recycler gives financial consideration for regulated metal property. Regulated article refers to any of the following: (1) Any metal article stamped, engraved, stenciled, or otherwise marked so as to identify it as having been the property of a governmental entity or public utility. (2) Any hard drawn copper electrical conductor, cable, or wire greater than three-eighths of one inch in diameter, stranded or solid; (3) Any aluminum conductor, cable, or wire greater than three-quarters of an inch in diameter, stranded or solid; (4) Any and all monument plaques, statues/sculptures composed of any metal, urns, or flower vases of any type metal. (5) Any containers used to store and dispense beverages of more than one individual serving such as a beer keg or commercial soft drink dispenser. Regulated metal property means any item(s) composed primarily of any nonferrous metals, but shall not include aluminum beverage containers of individual serving capacity, (i.e., aluminum cans). Scrap metal/recycling facility refers to an area used to receive, process, or store any form of metal that is already scrap for recycling or reuse, and which handles, removes, or disposes of waste as part of the processing. The definition shall include the area within an automobile recycling facility within which vehicles are drained, dismantled, sorted or recycled. Sheriff's office means the sheriff or his designee. Transaction ticket means a physical piece of paper bearing the customer's identification, latent print, and signature, and a description of the material purchased. These will be sequentially numbered with no break in that sequential number series. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-150. - Scrap metal recycling facility employees. (a) Qualifications. Employees of a scrap metal recycling center shall not be less than 17 years of age. Any employee who has been convicted of any felony or any crime involving theft, fraud or against property shall not be permitted to work on the premises in a position dealing with personal identification data of any persons, for a period of ten years from the date of conviction unless a longer time has been ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. Owners/managers/supervisors at the recycling facility must be able to provide physical proof of the legal right of any person working at that location to be employed in the state. (b) Approval for employment. Before any person may work on the regulated premises, it will be the employer's responsibility to run a criminal history on the applicant. The employer shall annually check all employees' criminal histories for any convictions of any felony or any crime involving theft, drugs, fraud or a crime against property. (c) Independent contractors. Independent contractors shall be required to obtain a criminal history check; and for the purpose of this article, independent contractors handling personal identification data of any person shall be considered employees and shall be permitted as employees, regardless of the business relationship with the owner or occupation tax certificate holder of any scrap metal recycling facility. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-151. - Application for occupation tax certificate; review of application. No action on any application by a salvage business for an occupation tax certificate shall be taken by the commissioners of the county until the sheriff of the county has reviewed such application and forwarded his recommendation to the county clerk. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-152. - Occupation tax certificate fee. The annual fee for each salvage business in the county shall be in an amount as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. Said fee shall be levied on an annual basis, based on the calendar year. Each salvage business shall pay his annual occupation tax certificate fee no later than March 1 of every calendar year. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-153. - Renewal of occupation tax certificate. Renewal applications shall be submitted by January 1 of the year for which such occupation tax certificate is required. The applicant must continue to meet the requirements set out in this article. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-154. - Transaction records to be maintained. All transaction information will be maintained on the business computer system and the original paper copy of each transaction ticket will be maintained at the facility for a period not less than two years. Both the computer records for these transactions and the paper transaction tickets will be available for law enforcement inspection and examination during all normal business hours. All required information will be machine printed or typed onto the transaction ticket, no hand written forms accepted. Every recycler shall have the affirmative duty to enter the following on the ticket: (1) The date of the transaction; (2) The name of the employee completing the transaction; (3) A detailed description of the materials purchased from the customer. The appropriate codes identifying the materials will also be used such as #1 copper, #2 copper, etc., the weights, quantity or volume of each material purchased. All catalytic converters will be named as such as well as the quantity; (4) The name, date of birth, race, sex, height, weight, hair color, state address, phone number, type of identification (DL or ID), state of issue, and the identification number; (5) The vehicle license plate number, state of issue, and the type of vehicle used to deliver the material to the recycle facility; (6) The price paid out for the materials purchased; (7) If payment is made by check, include the check number; (8) The signature of the customer; (9) The applicant shall maintain and retain on the business premises, for a period of two years the names, addresses, and date of birth of all persons currently or previously employed by such applicant both full time or part time. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-155. - Records maintenance. Every applicant operating as a scrap metal recycler within the county and any future applicants wishing to operate as a scrap metal recycler will be required to maintain records for two years and notify the county sheriff's office immediately upon receiving any of the regulated articles. Such report shall be submitted and shall contain the following information at a minimum: (1) Name and address of the facility; (2) Time of transaction; (3) Sequential number of transaction ticket; (4) Amount paid for materials purchased; (5) Full description of the person selling the materials to include, name, address, race, weight, height, date of birth, phone number, type of identification, issuing state, vehicle license plate number, type of vehicle; (6) Detailed description of materials purchased, including quantity/weight. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-156. - Receipt of goods from minors unlawful. It is unlawful for any employee, manager, supervisor or owner of a recycling facility operated within the county to accept any material/items from a minor with the exception of aluminum beverage cans. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-157. - Police holds on materials purchased; violation; fine and suspension of permit. Whenever a law enforcement officer shall have probable cause to suspect any property listed in the report is stolen property or constitutes evidence of a crime or that any individual has committed a crime or that possession of the property is criminal, the applicant shall be notified in writing not to sell, destroy, alter or remove the property from the physical boundaries of the recycling facility for a period of 15 calendar days. Prior to the expiration of the 15-day hold period the police department can issue a second notice to hold the items for an additional period of 30 calendar days. These hold notices will be in writing and will specifically identify the items and the specific transaction number to be held. Failure to comply with this section will result in the manager/owner of said facility being charged with violating this section which constitutes a misdemeanor and is punishable with a fine up $1,000.00 and a civil suspension of the applicant's work permit. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-158. - Identification required. (a) Each applicant shall require that any person pawning, pledging, or selling an article or articles shall display evidence of acceptable identification such as a duly issued state drivers' license or identification and the applicant shall record the driver's license number or other number of such evidence of identification on the required form for the transaction. (b) The applicant or his employee will have the affirmative duty to compare all pictures, physical descriptions and signatures on the identification presented and shall not transact any business with a person who appears to be presenting false or altered identification. If the identification presented is not a state issued identification, the applicant will have the affirmative duty of providing the listed address from the identification as well as a current state address on the transaction paperwork. The applicant is required to check the customer's identification for each transaction. If the records show identification other than that presented, this must be corrected during the current transaction. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-159. - Penalties for violation. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, any person failing to comply with any provision of this article, or other laws, ordinances, or regulation as may be passed by the county in regulating the business of a scrap metal recycling facility, shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of the occupation tax certificate issued hereunder. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-160. - Special consideration for certain transactions. (a) Every applicant shall immediately notify the police department by telephone (911) without delay if any person attempts to sell, purchase or has possession of any materials which reasonably appear to be used only by governments, utilities, railroads, or for specific purposes, such as guardrails, manhole covers, highway signs such as "Stop", fire hydrants, aluminum irrigation pipe, high voltage transmission lines, historical markers, cemetery plaques/vases/urns, light polices, power boxes, parking meters and bleachers. (b) Every applicant shall have the affirmative duty when accepting any motor vehicle in as scrap material to physically check and record the VIN information from said vehicle, along with vehicle type, manufacture, model, color. Any license plate attached to said vehicle will be removed from said vehicle and returned to the issuing state as required by law. No applicant will allow or accept the listed information from the person selling the vehicle as scrap without physically confirming the required information. All motor vehicles will be maintained separately on site, undamaged and unprocessed until the VIN information can be confirmed and checked through NCIC/GCIC by a county sheriff department officer. Any applicant failing to follow the requirements of this section will in violation of this article and will be charged as such. If the applicant has another employee physically check this information then the applicant must list that employee on the transaction ticket. (c) Every applicant will cause all catalytic converters purchased to be held separately from the rest of scrap materials purchased and will cause the transaction number to be affixed to said catalytic converters. All catalytic converters will remain on site for five working days prior to being processed and removed for sale. Any person bringing more than one catalytic converter over a three-month period in for sale will be paid by business check or voucher to be claimed after three working days. Instead of an identification number on the catalytic converter, the applicant may take a photo of the person holding the catalytic converter they are selling. (d) No applicant will accept or purchase any type of sculpture made of any type metal, any article which in any way appears to be related to cemetery artifacts such as head stones, plaques, flower vases, urns, or items normally related to religious signs or symbols which often would be displayed at a place of worship. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(1)) Sec. 22-161. - Prohibited practices. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person selling regulated metal property to a secondary metals recycler to give a false statement of ownership or to give a false or altered identification or vehicle tag number and receive money or other consideration from a secondary metals recycler in return for regulated metal property. (b) Note: Both persons selling to scrap metal recycling facilities and applicants of the scrap metal recycling facility can be charged under the Official Code of Georgia with either felony theft by receiving or misdemeanor theft by receiving depending upon the dollar value of any stolen property in their possession instead of under the violation provisions of this article. (Ord. of 4-6-2009) Sec. 22-162. - Duty of person who removes or stores a motor vehicle. (a) Any person who removes a motor vehicle from public property at the request of a law enforcement officer or stores such vehicle shall, if the owner of the vehicle or some person acting for the owner is not present, seek the identity of and address of all known owners of such vehicle from the law enforcement officer requesting removal of such, from such officer's agency, from a local law enforcement agency for the jurisdiction in which the remover's or storer's place of business is located, or from the state by direct electronic access as provided through its agencies and authorities within three business days of removal. The local law enforcement agency shall furnish such information to the person removing such vehicle within three business days after receipt of such request. (b) Any person who removes a motor vehicle from private property at the request of the property owner or stores such vehicle shall, if the owner of the vehicle or some person acting for the owner is not present, notify in writing a local law enforcement agency of the location of the vehicle, the manufacturer's vehicle identification number, license number, model, year, and make of the vehicle within three business days of the removal of such vehicle and shall seek from the local law enforcement agency or from the state by direct electronic access as provided through its agencies and authorities the identity and address of all known owners of such vehicle and any information indicating that such vehicle is a stolen motor vehicle. The local law enforcement agency shall furnish such information to the person removing such vehicle within three business days after receipt of such request. (c) If any motor vehicle removed under conditions set forth in subsection (a) or (b) of this section is determined to be a stolen motor vehicle, the local law enforcement officer or agency shall notify the state crime information center of the location of such motor vehicle within 72 hours after receiving notice that such motor vehicle is a stolen vehicle. (d) If any motor vehicle removed under conditions set forth in subsection (a) or (b) of this section is determined not to be a stolen vehicle or is not a vehicle being repaired by a repair facility or is not being stored by an insurance company providing insurance to cover damages to the vehicle, the person removing or storing such motor vehicle shall, within seven calendar days of the day such motor vehicle was removed or one business day after the information is furnished to the remover or storer pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) of this section, whichever is later, notify all owners, if known, by written acknowledgment signed thereby or by certified or registered mail or statutory overnight delivery, of the location of such motor vehicle, the fees connected with removal and storage of such motor vehicle, and the fact that such motor vehicle will be deemed abandoned under this article unless the owner, security interest holder, or lienholder redeems such motor vehicle within 30 days of the day such vehicle was removed. (e) If none of the owners redeems such motor vehicle as described in subsection (d) of this section, or if a vehicle being repaired by a repair facility or being stored by an insurance company providing insurance to cover damages to the vehicle becomes abandoned, the person removing or storing such motor vehicle shall, within seven calendar days of the day such vehicle became an abandoned motor vehicle, give notice by electronic means as provided by the state through its agencies and authorities, in writing, or by sworn statement, on the form prescribed by the state revenue commissioner, to the department of revenue with a research fee as fixed by rule or regulation payable to the department of revenue, stating the manufacturer's vehicle identification number, the license number, the fact that such vehicle is an abandoned motor vehicle, the model, year, and make of the vehicle, the date the vehicle became an abandoned motor vehicle, the date the vehicle was removed, and the present location of such vehicle and requesting the name and address of all owners of such vehicle. If the form submitted is rejected because of inaccurate or missing information, the person removing or storing the vehicle shall resubmit, within seven calendar days of the date of the rejection, a corrected notice form together with an additional research fee as fixed by rule or regulation payable to the department of revenue. Each subsequent corrected notice, if required, shall be submitted with an additional research fee as fixed by rule or regulation payable to the department of revenue. If a person removing or storing the vehicle has knowledge of facts which reasonably indicate that the vehicle is registered or titled in a certain other state, such person shall check the motor vehicle records of that other state in the attempt to ascertain the identity of the owner of the vehicle. Research requests may be submitted and research fees made payable to the office of the tax commissioner and deposited in the general fund for the county in which the remover's or storer's place of business is located in lieu of the department of revenue, but in like manner, if such office processes motor vehicle records of the department of revenue. (f) Upon ascertaining the owners of such motor vehicle, the person removing or storing such vehicle shall, within five calendar days, by certified or registered mail or statutory overnight delivery, notify all known owners of the vehicle of the location of such vehicle and of the fact that such vehicle is deemed abandoned and shall be disposed of if not redeemed. (g) If the identity of the owners of such motor vehicle cannot be ascertained, the person removing or storing such vehicle shall place an advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where such vehicle was obtained or, if there is no newspaper in such county, shall post such advertisement at the county courthouse in such place where other public notices are posted. Such advertisement shall run in the newspaper once a week for two consecutive weeks or shall remain posted at the courthouse for two consecutive weeks. The advertisement shall contain a complete description of the motor vehicle, its license and manufacturer's vehicle identification numbers, the location from where such vehicle was initially removed, the present location of such vehicle, and the fact that such vehicle is deemed abandoned and shall be disposed of if not redeemed. (h) Any person storing a vehicle under the provisions of this section shall notify the department of revenue if the vehicle is recovered, is claimed by the owner, is determined to be stolen, or for any reason is no longer an abandoned motor vehicle. Such notice shall be provided within seven calendar days of such event. (i) Any person who does not provide the notice and information required by this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as for a misdemeanor, shall not be entitled to any storage fees, shall not be eligible to contract with or serve on a rotation list providing wrecker services for this state or any political subdivision thereof, and shall not be licensed by any municipal authority to provide removal of improperly parked cars under O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13. (j) Any person who knowingly provides false or misleading information when providing any notice or information as required by this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. Sec. 22-163. - Disposition of abandoned vehicles. (a) The owner of any removed abandoned vehicles, before obtaining possession thereof, shall pay to the board of commissioners all reasonable costs, incidental to the removal, storage and locating of the owner. (b) Any person who removes or stores any motor vehicle which is or becomes an abandoned motor vehicle shall have a lien on such vehicle for the reasonable fees connected with such removal or storage plus the cost of any notification or advertisement. Such lien shall exist if the person moving or storing such vehicle is in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2. (c) Before any person can operate a salvage, mechanic shop, or junk yard business out of their residence or dwelling or property, he must abide by all code requirements and must have a current and valid occupation/business tax certificate. Failure to have a valid and current occupation/business tax certificate shall subject the violator to a fine up to $1,000.00 for each such offense. (Ord. of 4-6-2009(3)) Sec. 22-164. - Foreclosure of lien. All liens acquired under this article or state law shall be foreclosed as follows: (1) Any proceeding to foreclose a lien on an abandoned motor vehicle must be instituted within one year from the time the lien is recorded or is asserted by retention; (2) The person desiring to foreclose a lien on an abandoned motor vehicle shall, by certified or registered mail or statutory overnight delivery, make a demand upon the owners for the payment of the reasonable fees for removal and storage plus the costs of any notification or advertisement. Such written demand shall include an itemized statement of all charges and may be made concurrent with the notice required by O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2(f). Such demand shall be made on a form prescribed by rule or regulation of the department of revenue and shall notify the owner of his or her right to a judicial hearing to determine the validity of the lien. The demand shall further state that failure to return the written demand to the lien claimant, file with a court of competent jurisdiction a petition for a judicial hearing, and provide the lien claimant with a copy of such petition, all within ten days of delivery of the lien claimant's written demand, shall effect a waiver of the owner's right to such a hearing prior to sale. The form shall also provide the suspected owner with the option of disclaiming any ownership of the vehicle, and his affidavit to that effect shall control over anything contrary in the records of the department of revenue. No such written demand shall be required if the identity of the owner cannot be ascertained and the notice requirements of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2(g) have been complied with; (3) If, within ten days of delivery to the appropriate address of the written demand required by subsection (2) of this section, the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle fails to pay or file with the court a petition for a judicial hearing with a copy to the lien claimant in accordance with the notice provided pursuant to subsection (2) of this section, or if the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle cannot be ascertained, the person removing or storing the abandoned motor vehicle may foreclose such lien. The person asserting such lien may move to foreclose by making an affidavit to a court of competent jurisdiction, on a form prescribed by rule or regulation of the department of revenue, showing all facts necessary to constitute such lien and the amount claimed to be due. Such affidavit shall aver that the notice requirements of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2 have been complied with, and such affidavit shall also aver that a demand for payment in accordance with subsection (2) of this section has been made without satisfaction or without a timely filing of a petition for a judicial hearing or that the identity of the owner cannot be ascertained. The person foreclosing shall verify the statement by oath or affirmation and shall affix his or her signature thereto; (4) If no timely petition for a hearing has been filed with a court of competent jurisdiction, then, upon such affidavit's being filed by the lien claimant pursuant to subsection (3) of this section, the lien will conclusively be deemed a valid one and foreclosure thereof allowed; (5) If a petition for a hearing is filed with a court of competent jurisdiction within ten days after delivery of the lien claimant's demand, a copy of which demand shall be attached to the petition, the court shall set such a hearing within ten days of filing of the petition; (6) Upon the filing of such petition by an owner, neither the lien claimant nor the court may sell the motor vehicle, although possession of the motor vehicle may be retained by the lien claimant or obtained by the court in accordance with the order of the court which sets the date for the hearing; (7) If, after a full hearing, the court finds that a valid debt exists, then the court shall authorize foreclosure upon and sale of the motor vehicle subject to the lien to satisfy the debt if such debt is not otherwise immediately paid; (8) If the court finds the actions of the person asserting the lien in retaining possession of the motor vehicle were not taken in good faith, then the court, in its discretion, may award damages to the owner, any party which has been deprived of the rightful use of the vehicle, or the lessee due to the deprivation of the use of the motor vehicle; and (9) If an affidavit meeting the requirements of subsection (3) of this section is filed and no petition for a hearing is timely filed, or if, after a full hearing, the court determines that a valid debt exists, the court shall issue an order authorizing the sale of such motor vehicle. However, the holder of a security interest in or a lien on the vehicle, other than the holder of a lien created by O.C.G.A. § 40-11-4, shall have the right, in the order of priority of such security interest or lien, to pay the debt and court costs. If the holder of a security interest or lien does so pay the debt and court costs, he or she shall have the right to possession of the vehicle, and his security interest in or lien on such vehicle shall be increased by the amount so paid. A court order shall be issued to this effect, and in this instance there shall not be a sale of the vehicle. Sec. 22-165. - Proceeds of sale. The clerk of the court shall retain the remaining balance of the proceeds of a sale under O.C.G.A. § 40-11-6, after satisfaction of liens, security interests, and debts, for a period of 12 months; and, if no claim has been filed against such proceeds by the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle or any interested party, then he or she shall pay such remaining balance as follows: (1) If the abandoned motor vehicle came into the possession of the person creating the lien other than at the request of a peace officer, the proceeds of the sale shall be divided equally and paid into the general fund of the county in which the sale was made and into the general fund of the municipality, if any, in which the sale was made; (2) If the abandoned motor vehicle came into the possession of the person creating the lien at the request of a police officer of a municipality, the proceeds of the sale shall be paid into the general fund of the municipality; (3) If the abandoned motor vehicle came into the possession of the person creating the lien at the request of a county sheriff, deputy sheriff, or county police officer, the proceeds of the sale shall be paid into the general fund of the county in which the sale was made; (4) If the abandoned motor vehicle came into the possession of the person creating the lien at the request of a member of the state patrol or other employee of the state, the proceeds of the sale shall be paid into the general fund of the county in which the sale was made. Secs. 22-166—22-175. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PAWNSHOPS[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Pawnbrokers generally, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; municipal authority to license and regulate pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136.
Sec. 22-176. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Employee means any person employed or allowed to perform duties, whether or not such person receives a salary, wages or compensation or consideration, but not including the person covered on the license or renewal application. Goods, whenever used in this article, shall carry its normal meaning, and further it should be construed in the broadest sense allowable and should include all forms of personal property. Owner means any person, partner or stockholder owning 25 percent or more of a business. Pawnshop means any business which shall, in any manner, lend or advance money or other things for profit on the pledge of possession of personal property, or other valuable things other than securities or written evidences of indebtedness, or which deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling the same back to the seller at a stipulated price. Sec. 22-177. - Licenses required. Every person doing business in the county as a pawnshop, prior to commencing business, shall make proper application for and receive the appropriate business license or licenses as set forth in this article. Sec. 22-178. - Application for license and permit. (a) Applicants for a license or permit shall file a written, sworn application on a form provided by the county clerk, signed by the applicant if an individual, by the partner making application if a partnership, or by the president if a corporation, with the clerk of the county showing: (1) The name or address of the principals, agents and employees of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the county; the local address or addresses of such person or persons; capacity in which such person or persons will act (as proprietor, agent, employee or otherwise); the name and the address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state it is incorporated; (2) The fingerprints of the principals, agents or employees of the applicant's business and other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the sheriff, subject to the approval of the board of commissioners, the good character of such persons to carry on the business; (3) The place or places in the county where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business, the zoning district at the place or places, and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; (4) The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six months preceding the date of the application conducted any other type of business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address or office in which such business was conducted; (5) A brief statement of the nature and the character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers; (6) Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime or violations of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; (7) Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and (8) Such other information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the county clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. (b) The application shall state thereon that, "It is unlawful for any person to make a false statement on this application." Any false statement made on the application form will be cause to revoke the license issued thereunder and also shall constitute a violation of state law. Sec. 22-179. - Exclusions; exceptions. Businesses which limit the purchase of used valuables to the acceptance of trade-ins for credit for new goods or the dispensing of refunds in regard to valuables previously purchased from the business, shall not be required to be licensed as prescribed by this article nor to be covered under the provisions of this article. Sec. 22-180. - Employee permit. Each person authorized or allowed to conduct any place of business covered under this article shall be considered an employee and must have an approved license or an employee permit, and this permit must be displayed along with the business license in accordance with license display requirements. Sec. 22-181. - Business license fee. All businesses licensed under this article shall pay a license fee per calendar year in the amount provided in the county fees. Any co-owner, agent, employee or any other persons authorized to transact business, other than the licensee, shall be required to have employee permits for each license under which he operates or transacts business. There shall be no fee for employee permits issued under this section. Licenses and permits issued hereunder shall be a personal privilege and shall not be transferable, except that employee permits may be transferred from one licensed business to another. There shall be no proration or refund of any license fee. Sec. 22-182. - Character qualifications. No license or employee permit shall be issued to or renewed for any person who conducts or is employed in a business in which such owner or employee has, within ten years of issuance or renewal, been convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, any felony involving any federal or state offense or any federal or state misdemeanor involving theft-related offenses, unless a longer time has been ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The licensee will submit the identity of all owners and employees to the county clerk on a continuing basis as changes occur. This information is to be forwarded to the sheriff's office for the purpose of allowing a complete check in order that these character qualifications are fulfilled prior to the issuance or renewal of any license or permit issued under this article. Sec. 22-183. - Location of businesses. All businesses licensed under this article shall be located in strict compliance with county zoning regulations and at a location with an identifiable street address, which shall be stated on the license or renewal application along with other required information; and no business licensed under this article shall change its address without giving advance notice to the county clerk and the sheriff's office, and receiving approval of the change, the approval being granted if the new location complies with this article and the city zoning regulations. Sec. 22-184. - Records to be kept; inspection; violations. (a) All pawnshops, in addition to other records, shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate description of all property received by or pledged or sold to them. Such description shall include the brand name of the article, any identifying mark, number, initial, social security number or name of any person or company and a statement of the kind of material of which it is made. A permanent bound set of the pawn tickets shall constitute the book required by this article. (b) In such books there shall be entered also the name, age, address, signature, and identification number from a driver's license or similar identification of the person by who same was delivered, deposited or sold, the name of the agent or employee receiving the item, the time when such transaction occurred, the price paid for the goods purchased and the check number issued, if applicable. (c) All books and records required by this article and items pledged or sold hereunder shall at all times be subject to inspection and examination by any city, county, state or federal law enforcement officer. Any person engaged in any business licensed under this article who shall fail or refuse to keep the records as provided in this article, or who shall make false entries concerning the transaction or who shall fail or refuse to permit an inspection by any of the aforementioned law enforcement officers of the records and of the property deposited with or sold to such person shall be guilty of a violation of this article. (d) Any licensee found to have violated this section shall receive a written warning upon such finding. If a licensee is found to have violated this subsection a second time, the licensee's license shall be suspended for a period of two years and no person living at the same address as the licensee may become licensed under this article without first showing to the satisfaction of the county that the business will be totally separate from, independent of, and unaffiliated with the licensee whose license has been suspended. Sec. 22-185. - Standard forms required. All businesses licensed under this article shall use a standard form for pawn and a standard form for purchase, and no ticket may be used for a dual purpose. Standard forms may differ only by the name of the business and business address. The design of this form shall be provided by the sheriff's office and the forms shall be numbered and chronologically used and sent to the sheriff's office. Each number missing from the chronological sequence shall be considered a separate violation of this article. Sec. 22-186. - Weekly report. (a) Every licensee shall prepare a daily report for the sheriff's office, in such form as may be prescribed by the sheriff's office, of all property pledged to or bought by the licensee during the preceding 24 hours ending at 8:00 p.m. on the effective date of the report. In addition to any other information required by the sheriff's office, the report shall disclose: (1) The name and address of the licensee; (2) Time of transaction; (3) Serial numbers of pawn tickets; (4) Full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry, and all identifying names, marks, and numbers; (5) A description of persons pledging, selling, or pawning; including name, address, information from such person's driver's license or government-issued identification, including weight, height, and eye color; and (6) Serial numbers on items. (b) Insufficient or incomplete reports shall be rejected. (c) Any licensee or employee who fails or refuses to prepare and keep reports as provided in this section or makes false entries concerning a transaction or who fails or refuses to permit an inspection or examination of the report by any police officer, designated by the chief of police to conduct such inspections, shall constitute a violation of this Code, which shall be punishable as provided in this article. Sec. 22-187. - Identification required. Each licensee shall require any person pawning, pledging, or selling an article or articles to display his government-issued identification that, at a minimum, contains a photograph, date of birth, height, weight, eye color, race and gender, as well as the identification number, driver's license number or social security number of the person, the type of identification and the name of the board of county commissioners issuing such identification. The licensee shall record all of the above information from such identification. Sec. 22-188. - Purchased articles not to be disposed of for ten days after acquisition. Every business licensed under this article shall hold on the premises designated in the license for doing business every item purchased for at least ten working days not including holidays or weekends, before disposing of same by sale, transfer or shipment. The provisions of this section shall not apply to items purchased from licensed wholesalers in the normal course of business. Sec. 22-189. - Pawned articles not to be disposed of for 30 days after acquisition. Every business licensed under this article shall hold pawned goods for at least 30 days, unless redeemed by the owner or on authority of the owner, before disposing of same by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. Sec. 22-190. - Display of goods pledged or purchased. (a) For a period of ten working days from the date of purchase and 30 days from the date of pledge, unless redeemed by or by authority of the person who pledged the goods, all goods purchased or pawned, and required to be included in the records and reports specified in this article, shall be kept on the licensed premises. A copy of the pawn ticket or the number of the original pawn ticket shall be affixed to each item that is subject to the provisions of this section. (b) Any person desiring to examine any merchandise shall first file with the sheriff's office an incident report or stolen property report and upon giving notice, in writing to the owner or employee, which notice shall include a full description of the stolen items including all identifying characteristics, the person's name, address, identification and signature, such individual shall be allowed to examine any merchandise of the type described in the request on the premises. (c) Such written information shall be kept in sequential, dated order in a permanent file or book. This record shall be kept in addition to all other records required herein. Sec. 22-191. - Alteration. Any items required to be kept or displayed under the provisions of this article shall be kept in their original form as they existed when first purchased, and their physical characteristics shall not be altered in any numerical or material manner. Sec. 22-192. - Erasures or obliterations or write-overs or type-overs are not allowed. No persons licensed under this article shall erase, obliterate, type over, write over or in any way cause the original entry on the records required by this article to become illegible. All pawn or purchase tickets filled out in error shall be sent to the sheriff's office in their numbered order along with the weekly reports and shall have the word "VOID" typed or written across the front. Such entry shall not be used to cause the original entry to be illegible. If an error is made, and the ticket is still to be used, then a single line shall be drawn through the incorrect entry. This line shall not cause the original entry to be illegible, and the correct information entry shall be made on the next available area. Sec. 22-193. - Records maintained for four years. The record for each pawn or purchase transaction regulated by this article shall be maintained for a period of not less than four years from date of the transaction. Sec. 22-194. - Dealing with minors. It is unlawful for any person licensed under this article to receive in pawn or in purchase any goods of any character or of any description from any person who has not attained the age of 17 years. Sec. 22-195. - Hours of operation. All businesses licensed under this article shall close their establishments and cease transacting any business no later than 11:00 p.m. each day and begin their operation and commence transacting business at no time before 7:00 a.m. each day. Sec. 22-196. - Business transactions to be conducted in licensed premises; exception. (a) No business transactions by any business licensed under this article shall be conducted outside the building designated as the normal place to conduct transactions unless the business does not have a building. (b) The term "business transaction" means any part of a business including the inspection or appraisal of any goods when it is possible for such goods to be taken outside the building where transactions are normally made ("possible" being here used in the broadest sense); and no person other than those possessing a license or employee permit shall be allowed to conduct any form of business transaction either inside the establishment or on any part of outside land area covered under address of the license. Sec. 22-197. - Articles with serial numbers removed or altered may not be accepted. No business licensed under this article shall accept any article which has had the serial number altered, obliterated or removed from such article or which the person who is making the business transaction knows should have a serial number on it. Licensees shall immediately report any attempted business transaction of this nature to the sheriff's office. Sec. 22-198. - Compliance with records requirements required for pawn acceptance. No business licensed under this article shall take any item in pawn or purchase or take full possession or title thereto, without entering such transaction of such goods on his books and on the standard forms as provided for in this article. Sec. 22-199. - Ownership of other pawn business in other town or same town. Any owner of a business licensed under this article shall not transfer goods from one business, where he has a minority or majority ownership, to another business without the goods meeting all regulations of the ordinances of the county regarding pawnshops. Sec. 22-200. - Violations; penalties. (a) Any person licensed under this article who shall do any of the following acts shall be in violation of this article: (1) Fail to make any entry of any required item in the permanent record book; (2) Make any false entry therein; (3) Falsify, obliterate, destroy or remove from his place of business such permanent record book so that information is illegible; (4) Refuse to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect such permanent record book, or any goods in his possession, during the ordinary hours of business or any reasonable time, or refuse to allow any member of the general public to inspect goods in his possession being held under pawn or purchase within seven days of purchase and 30 days of the item being pawned, during ordinary hours of business; (5) Fail to maintain a record of each pawn or purchase transaction for at least four years; (6) Violate any other provisions of this article. (b) Operation of any business under this article in violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense for each day of operation. Sec. 22-201. - Inspection. As a condition of the granting of the license under this article, every licensee agrees to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer, pursuant to his official duties, to be and remain about the licensed premises without the formality of a warrant, provided the officer does not interfere in the licensee's operation. Sec. 22-202. - Non-formed precious metals. It is unlawful for any person licensed under this article to purchase precious metals in a melted, smelted or non-formed state unless the purchase is from a registered dealer in precious metals. Sec. 22-203. - Stolen items. Every person licensed under this article shall, immediately upon request, turn over to the sheriff's office every item believed by the sheriff's office to be a stolen item. The sheriff's office shall furnish a property receipt, including the case number, to the dealer surrendering such item, and such item shall be returned to the dealer only after it has been determined that such item is not stolen. If it is determined such item is stolen, it shall be returned to its lawful owner. Sec. 22-204. - Sale of prohibited weapons. It is unlawful for any licensee to sell, offer for sale, or expose for sale any weapons, the sale of which are prohibited by county ordinance, state law, or federal law or regulation. Any licensee or employee thereof violating this section shall constitute a violation of this section and shall be punishable as provided in this article. Sec. 22-205. - Security cameras required. (a) Any establishment which is licensed by the county to engage in the business of operating as a pawnshop and which is open to the public for business any day of the week is required to install security cameras and recording mechanisms of a type and number capable of recording evidentiary quality images for the prosecution of criminal cases, or for such other uses as may be deemed authorized by law. (b) Cameras and recording mechanisms meeting the requirements of this section must be capable of producing a retrievable image on videotape or other medium that can be made a permanent record and can be enlarged through projection or other means. Cameras and recording mechanisms meeting the requirements of this section shall be maintained in proper working order at all times and shall be subject to inspection by the sheriff's office. (c) Security videos must have a shelf life of 15 calendar days from time of daily taping. The security video must be maintained at the licensee's place of business in an unaltered state and be available for inspection by the sheriff's office. (d) In the event that the security cameras and recording mechanisms become inoperative, any licensee or employee thereof shall not be in violation of this section for conducting business if the licensee is diligently pursuing repairs of such system; provided that such repairs must be completed within ten days after such system becomes inoperative. (e) Any licensee or employee thereof violating this section shall constitute a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided in this article. Sec. 22-206. - Applicability of and conflict with state law. This article is to be construed as consistent with state law. However, these provisions are to be applied in lieu of state law and state fee and registration requirements whenever possible. It is the intent of this law that all duties delegated to the chief law enforcement officer of the county shall be exercised as provided in this article. Secs. 22-207—22-217. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - TIMBER HARVESTING
Sec. 22-218. - Purpose. (a) It is the purpose and intent of this article to ensure that operators engaging in harvesting timber in the county be responsible for any damage beyond normal wear and tear inflicted on the county road system or right-of-way within areas of ingress and egress. (b) It is also the purpose of this article to ensure that the county tax commissioner knows of the timber being harvested, and that the timber taxes are paid to the county tax commissioner. (Ord. of 9-9-2013) Sec. 22-219. - Definitions. The following words, terms or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Bond means a surety bond written by a company licensed by the state insurance commissioner. The term also includes, at the discretion of an applicant, a cash bond or bank letter of credit. County road means any and all roads that are part of the county road system, delineated in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1, and intended or used for the passage of motor vehicles by the public. Damage means any and all injury to the road surface, road base or right-of-way of a road within 100 feet of any designated entrance or exit from the timber harvesting site, including, but not limited to, the following: (1) Diversion of or the filing of any drainage ditch, culvert or pipe parallel to or underneath a county road, so as to restrain or redirect the flow of water. (2) The operation of any vehicle, machinery or equipment which gouges, rips, breaks, depresses or otherwise defaces a public road beyond normal wear and tear. (3) The continued ingress or egress to and from a county road at a particular location which results in a buildup of rock, gravel, mud, dirt or other materials, which present hazards to other persons using the county road for authorized purposes. (4) The creation or erection of any dam, berm, ditch or wall which restrains the natural flow of waters and results in the redirecting of waters onto the road surface of any county road. (5) The term does not include normal wear and tear to county roads from use of such roads by an operator in the course of transporting timber or pulpwood harvested in the county. Enforcement officer means the county road superintendent or code enforcement. Multitract operator includes the meanings included in the definition of operator, but, in addition, means an operator who owes, or has contracts to cut multiple tracts, or owns, or has contracts to cut a very large tract and will cut or subcontract the cutting of multiple tracts, or large tracts to independent contract cutters. Operator means any person, entity, individual, partnership, corporation, association or other organization including the officers, agents and employees thereof carrying out the activities contemplated by this article. Repair means the repair of a county road to its condition prior to the occurrence of damage caused by transporting timber harvested in the county. Rights-of-way means the shoulder, front slope, ditch, drain and back slope of a county road, whether owned by title or otherwise. (Ord. of 9-9-2013) Sec. 22-220. - Enforcement. (a) If the operator fails to abide by the terms and conditions of this article, the county may issue an immediate stop work order. If the operator fails to abide by the stop work order, the operator shall pay a penalty up to $1,000.00 per day for each day the operator proceeds after the delivery of the stop work order, and, in addition, the operator shall pay all expenses the county incurs in the enforcement of this article, including, but not limited to, court costs and reasonable attorney's fees. (b) The county sheriff is authorized to assist the county in the enforcement of this article. (Ord. of 9-9-2013) Sec. 22-221. - Notice required. (a) All persons or firms harvesting standing timber in any unincorporated area of the county for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts or woodchips to any wood yard or processing plant located inside or outside this state shall provide notice of such harvesting operations to the county governing authority or the designated agent thereof prior to cutting any such timber. (1) Prior written notice should be required of any person or firm harvesting such timber for each separate tract to be harvested thereby, shall be in such form as prescribed by rules or regulations of the director of the state forestry commission, and shall consist of: a. A map of the area which identifies the location of the tract to be harvested and as to those trucks which will be traveling to and from such tract for purposes of picking up and hauling loads of cut forest products, the main point of ingress to such tract from a public road and, if different, the main point of egress from such tract to a public road; b. A statement as to whether the timber will be removed pursuant to a lump sum sale, per unit sale, or owner harvest for purposes of ad valorem taxation under O.C.G.A. § 48-5-7.5; c. The name, address and daytime telephone number of the timber seller if the harvest is pursuant to a lump sum or per unit sale or of the timber owner if the harvest is an owner harvest; and d. The name, business address, business telephone number and nighttime or emergency telephone number of the person or firm harvesting such timber. (2) Notice may be submitted in person, by transmission of an electronic record via telefacsimile or such other means as approved by the governing authority or by mail. (3) Persons or firms subject to such notice requirement shall deliver a bond or letter of credit, in which case notice shall not be or remain effective for such harvesting operations unless and until the person or firm providing such notice had delivered to the governing authority or its designated agent a valid surety bond, executed by a surety corporation authorized to transact business in the state, protecting the county against any damage caused by such person or firm in an amount specified by the governing authority not exceeding $5,000.00 or, at the option of the person or firm harvesting the timber, a valid irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank or savings and loan association, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 7-1-4, in the amount of and in lieu of such bond. For purposes of this subsection, any such surety bond or letter of credit shall be valid only for the calendar year in which delivered. (4) Notice shall be effective for such harvesting operation on such tract within such unincorporated area of the county upon receipt of the same by the governing authority or its designated agent and compliance with the requirements of subsection (b)(3) of this section and until such time as the person or firm giving such notice has completed the harvesting operation for such tract; however, any subsequent change in the facts required to be provided for purpose of such notice shall be reported to the governing authority or its designated agent within three business days after such change. (5) Notice requirements shall be applicable to any timber harvested on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derived. (6) Violation of the notice requirements of this section shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding $500.00. (b) The county shall not require any person or firm harvesting standing timber in the county for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts or wood chips to any wood yard or processing plant located inside or outside this state to provide any notice of or plan or security for such harvesting or hauling of forest products except as provided by this section. The county shall not require any person or firm harvesting standing timber in the county for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts or wood chips to any wood yard or processing plant located inside or outside this state to obtain any permit for such harvesting or hauling of forest products, including, without limitation, any permit for any new driveway in connection with timber harvesting operations; however, this subsection shall not otherwise limit the authority of a county or municipality to regulate roads or streets under its jurisdiction in accordance with O.C.G.A. title 32. (Ord. of 9-9-2013) Sec. 22-222. - Multitract operators. A multitract operator may post a single bond, on an annual basis, for the cutting of timber in the county. However, either the multitract operator, or his subcontractors, remains obligated to apply for a permit for each and every cutting each separate operator performs in the county, and the individual subcontractor and the multitract operator shall be individually and jointly bound to the county for the faithful compliance with the terms of this article. A contractual relationship between the multitract operator and subcontractors do not insulate either from the faithful performance of the duties required by this article or from the application of the enforcement provisions by the county against either or both parties. The multitract operator shall furnish to the county written authorization for a subcontractor to make application under the multitract bond and, to cut a tract in the county under the multitract bond, or the multi tract operator shall make the application in person. (Ord. of 9-9-2013) Sec. 22-223. - Damage to county roads. It shall be unlawful for any operator engaged in transporting forest products over county roads to damage county roads or county rights-of-way at points of ingress or egress in the county. (Ord. of 9-9-2013) Sec. 22-224. - Operational requirements. (a) Roads. The use of county roads by an operator transmitting timber or pulpwood must not endanger the traveling public; where damage does occur, the roads so damaged shall be restored to their previous condition, including, but not limited to, removal of debris and mud and replacement of gravel. Trucks or other equipment used in the harvesting operation shall not be allowed to park on the right-of-way for extended periods of time. (b) Warning signs. Any firm, company or person operating on the public right-of-way shall be required to post warning signs at least 500 feet on both sides of the temporary driveway adequately warning oncoming traffic of persons, vehicles, equipment or machinery entering the roadway. (c) Termination.
